snippet.textDisplay:
Standing here
I realize
You are just like me
Trying to make history
But who’s to judge
The right from wrong
When our guard is down
I think we’ll both agree
That
Violence breeds violence
But in the end it has to be this way
I’ve carved my own path
You followed your wrath
But maybe we’re both the same
The world has turned
And so many have burned
But nobody is to blame
Yet staring across this barren wasted land
I feel new life will be born
Beneath the blood stained sand
Beneath the blood stained sand

snippet.textDisplay: @Blade Brent  I think the idea was the nanomachines could only be used to protect a single point at any given time. Not sure if that's what they were aiming for but it seems fairly consistent with the other scenes we see through the fight and cut scenes.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think that while Armstrong's ideals make sense, that we should all strive for what we believe in and not what we're told to believe in, I also think he takes it too far. He believes that only the strong should survive; that's the same logic that applied during the age of Social Darwinism, and that was a hellhole for people who lacked the ability to adapt.

In the end, Raiden follows through on fighting for his own cause but he doesn't end up hurting those he cares for in the process. He won.
snippet.textOriginal:
I think that while Armstrong's ideals make sense, that we should all strive for what we believe in and not what we're told to believe in, I also think he takes it too far. He believes that only the strong should survive; that's the same logic that applied during the age of Social Darwinism, and that was a hellhole for people who lacked the ability to adapt.

In the end, Raiden follows through on fighting for his own cause but he doesn't end up hurting those he cares for in the process. He won.

snippet.textDisplay: Revengeance at once demonises Armstrong's cult of strength but acknowledges that Raiden wouldn't have won unless he was stronger - physically. The message seems to be 'might makes right' regardless of innocence or justice (child soldiers). Raiden doesn't say he's stronger because he believes in good - indeed, the Ripper enjoys straight-up murdering people. Morally speaking Revengeance is kinda grey, but the deciding factor is, as you said, empathy: Raiden has it, Armstrong hasn't.
snippet.textOriginal: Revengeance at once demonises Armstrong's cult of strength but acknowledges that Raiden wouldn't have won unless he was stronger - physically. The message seems to be 'might makes right' regardless of innocence or justice (child soldiers). Raiden doesn't say he's stronger because he believes in good - indeed, the Ripper enjoys straight-up murdering people. Morally speaking Revengeance is kinda grey, but the deciding factor is, as you said, empathy: Raiden has it, Armstrong hasn't.

snippet.textDisplay: You are correct sir. Armstrong's ethos is basically 'strength is good, so everyone should be strong'. This sounds halfway decent, until you realise that Armstrong curiously forgets to mention what he thinks should happen to those who either can't or don't want to be strong. Raiden beats him at his own game so he isn't even mad when he dies: he can't imagine someone stronger than him genuinely wanting to *protect* the weak because strong people only respect strength, right?

How did I survive?

Nanomachines, son.

snippet.textDisplay: That world DOES already exist, but unfortunately for the single individuals who want their freedom in it, the consistent victor in history has been, is presently, and may forever more be SOCIETY... and we are the ones It exerts Its authority over while also becoming Its agents.  Just as It ultimately exerted Its will over Armstrong, It used Raiden as Its sword to do so.  Now THERE'S a meme to contemplate...
snippet.textOriginal: That world DOES already exist, but unfortunately for the single individuals who want their freedom in it, the consistent victor in history has been, is presently, and may forever more be SOCIETY... and we are the ones It exerts Its authority over while also becoming Its agents.  Just as It ultimately exerted Its will over Armstrong, It used Raiden as Its sword to do so.  Now THERE'S a meme to contemplate...

snippet.textDisplay: As I've watched playthroughs of this boss fight (because I don't have the luxury of having a Playstation let alone this game), I cannot help but have warm feelings about the two people with the same character but different developed ideals clashing.  I may even want the sort of world Armstrong was trying to create, but knew that if Raiden was stronger, then by HIS will, that idealized world that accepted him as the authority would still be destroyed and replaced with the old world he fought for.
snippet.textOriginal: As I've watched playthroughs of this boss fight (because I don't have the luxury of having a Playstation let alone this game), I cannot help but have warm feelings about the two people with the same character but different developed ideals clashing.  I may even want the sort of world Armstrong was trying to create, but knew that if Raiden was stronger, then by HIS will, that idealized world that accepted him as the authority would still be destroyed and replaced with the old world he fought for.

snippet.textDisplay:
senator armstrong really makes a strange case for his views.
it's like every punch and blow he uses to punctuate his point shows you just how angry he is at the weak for shackling the strong, he hates the fact that they have that right, he hates that might no longer makes right, that war itself has become pointless.
Were he not slaughtering children to turn them into cyborgs i'd almost find myself relating to his frustration.
well played kojima, well played.
I'm gonna go beat up grizzlies now...

snippet.textDisplay: I respect and love Platinums Game's games (boy that sounded redundant). Thier gameplay feels amazingly polished in their games and has a classic arcade style to it. The only thing with them I have a deal with is the story in their games. If your going to be over the top, stick to it! They try to slip serious tones and storytelling in Bayonetta and from what I've heard in this too. Your games are batshit crazy guys, don't try to tell me a emotional story while I'm a cyborg ninja mkay? xD
